raw_text:
Firefox browser takes on Microsoft
 
 Microsoft's Internet Explorer has a serious rival in the long-awaited Firefox 1.0 web browser, which has just been released.
 
 Few people get excited when some new software is released, especially when the program is not a game or a music or movie player. But the release of the first full version of Firefox has managed to drum up a respectable amount of pre-launch fervour. Fans of the software have banded together to raise cash to pay for an advert in the New York Times announcing that version 1.0 of the browser is available. The release of Firefox 1.0 on 9 November might even cause a few heads to turn at Microsoft because the program is steadily winning people away from the software giant's Internet Explorer browser.
 
 Firefox has been created by the Mozilla Foundation which was started by former browser maker Netscape back in 1998. Much of the development work done since then has gone into Firefox which made its first appearance under this name in February. Earlier incarnations, but which had the same core technology, were called Phoenix and Firebird. Since then the software has been gaining praise and converts, not least because of the large number of security problems that have come to light in Microsoft's Internet Explorer. Rivals to IE got a boost in late June when two US computer security organisations warned people to avoid the Microsoft program to avoid falling victim to a serious vulnerability.
 
 Internet monitoring firm WebSideStory has charted the growing population of people using the Firefox browser and says it is responsible for slowly eroding the stranglehold of IE. Before July this year, according to WebSideStory, Internet Explorer was used by about 95% of web surfers. That figure had remained static for years. In July the IE using population dropped to 94.7% and by the end of October stood at 92.9%. The Mozilla Foundation claims that Firefox has been downloaded almost eight million times and has publicly said it would be happy to garner 10% of the Windows- using, net-browsing population. Firefox is proving popular because, at the moment, it has far fewer security holes than Internet Explorer and has some innovations lacking in Microsoft's program. For instance, Firefox allows the pages of different websites to be arranged as tabs so users can switch easily between them. It blocks pop-ups, has a neat way of finding text on a page and lets you search through the pages you have browsed.
 
 One of the most powerful features of Firefox is the many hundreds of extras, or extensions, produced for it. The Mozilla Foundation is an open source organisation which means that the creators of the browser are happy for others to play around with the core code for the program. This has resulted in many different add-ons or extensions for the browser which now include everything from a version of the familiar Google toolbar to a Homeland Security monitor that keep users aware of current threat levels. Firefox, which used to be called Firebird and before that Phoenix, also has a growing number of vocal net-based fans. A campaign co-ordinated by the Spread Firefox website attempted to raise the $50,000 needed for a full page advert in the New York Times. The campaign set itself a target of recruiting 2500 volunteers. Ten days in to the campaign 10,000 people had signed up and now about $250,000 has been raised. The ad is due to run sometime in a three-week period in late November/early December. The surplus cash will be used to help keep the Mozilla Foundation running. Microsoft is facing a growing challenge to IE's hold on the web using population. from alternative browsers such as Opera, Safari, Amaya and even Netscape.
llama3.2:1b: Microsoft's Internet Explorer has been challenged by Firefox 1.0, which has gained popularity with some users due to its fewer security holes and innovative features. The Mozilla Foundation created Firefox in 1998 and released the first version under this name in February. Since then, the software has grown in praise and converts, partly due to its large number of security problems being addressed by Microsoft. Internet monitoring firm WebSideStory reports that Firefox is responsible for eroding IE's market share, with Internet Explorer now used by 92.9% of web surfers, down from a static figure of 94.7% in July and 95% before that.
llama3.2:3b: Firefox browser releases version 1.0, winning people away from Internet Explorer with its security features and innovations like tabbed browsing, pop-up blocking, and user extensions. The Mozilla Foundation claims Firefox has been downloaded almost eight million times, and the release of version 1.0 may cause Microsoft to take notice as the browser gains popularity, eroding IE's hold on the web surfing population.
gemma2:2b: Firefox 1.0, developed by the Mozilla Foundation, has been gaining traction as a rival to Microsoft's Internet Explorer.  The browser offers improved security, innovative features (like tabbed browsing), and a vast ecosystem of extensions, drawing users away from IE.  Its popularity is fueled by user-driven campaigns, including one that secured funding for a New York Times advertisement.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Firefox browser becomes internet rival after Internet Explorer release. Fans of Firefox have raised money by raising $50, 000 for an ad campaign in a New York Times advertisement to attract more people to the Firefox browser. It is hoped that this will help keep the Mozilla Foundation running.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Firefox 1.0, developed by Mozilla, competes with Internet Explorer and has gained popularity due to fewer security issues and innovations compared to Microsoft's browser. Firefox surpassed 8 million downloads in just a few months, becoming the second-most popular web browser after IE. It also features extensions that add various tools like Google toolbar or Homeland Security monitors, making it more user-friendly than its predecessor versions. The project has raised $50,000 for a NY Times advert, aiming to attract 2500 volunteers and use surplus funds to maintain the organization's operations. Firefox is challenging IE's dominance in web surfing.
qwen2.5:3b:
Firefox browser takes on Microsoft

Microsoft's Internet Explorer faces competition with Firefox 1.0, which has gained significant pre-launch interest. The Mozilla Foundation created Firefox, now heralding its first full version release in November 9th, attracting attention from both industry giants like Microsoft and the public. Firefox’s rise is partly due to IE's security issues highlighted by US computer security organizations. Firefox offers fewer vulnerabilities compared to IE, features like customizable tabs and pop-up blockers, making it increasingly popular among users. The browser's popularity has been measured at almost eight million downloads, with Mozilla aiming for 10% market share of Windows browsers. With the release campaign raising over $250K, a full-page ad in New York Times is planned to enhance Firefox’s visibility against IE.
opencoder:1.5b: Firefox browser takes on Microsoft Internet Explorer has a serious rival in the long-awaited Firefox 1.0 web browser, released by few people excitedly when some new software is released. Fervour due to fans of the software have banded together to raise cash to pay for an advert in the New York Times. The creation of Firefox by Mozilla Foundation has contributed to its popularity. Features of Firefox include a large number of security holes and numerous innovative extensions. It allows switching between different tabs, searching through pages and even creating new ones while protecting against pop-ups. Many of its potential users are determined to keep using it.
smollm:1.7b:
Microsoft has been trying to compete with Firefox for years by releasing new versions of its Internet Explorer browser. However, Firefox has managed to gain popularity due to its many innovative features and open-source nature. One of the most powerful features of Firefox is its ability to allow users to add custom extensions or add-ons to their browsing experience. This has resulted in a growing number of users who use Firefox as their primary web browser.

The Mozilla Foundation, which produces Firefox, is an open source organization that allows developers to contribute and modify the code for the program. This has led to many different add-ons or extensions being developed for Firefox, each one offering a unique feature or improvement over the original program. For example, there are now several versions of Google toolbar available as an extension for Firefox, allowing users to access their favorite search engine without leaving the browser.

The campaign to raise money for a full page advert in the New York Times is a great example of how the Mozilla Foundation uses its open-source nature to promote itself and attract new supporters. The campaign set itself a target of recruiting 250,000 volunteers to help spread the word about the importance of Firefox and the need for more alternative browsers. From this point on, the campaign will be running until late November/early December, with the goal of raising $50,000 in cash to support the full page advert.

Microsoft has been trying to compete with Firefox for years by releasing new versions of its Internet Explorer browser. However, Firefox has managed to gain popularity due to its many innovative features and open-source nature. One of the most powerful features of Firefox is its ability to allow users to add custom extensions or add-ons to their browsing experience. This has resulted in a growing number of users who use Firefox as their primary web browser.

The Mozilla Foundation, which produces Firefox, is an open source organization that allows developers to contribute and modify the code for the program. This has led to many different add-ons or extensions being developed for Firefox, each one offering a unique feature or improvement over the original program. For example, there are now several versions of Google toolbar available as an extension for Firefox, allowing users to access their favorite search engine without leaving the browser.

The campaign to raise money for a full page advert in the New York Times is a great example of how the Mozilla Foundation uses its open-source nature to promote itself and attract new supporters. The campaign set itself a target of recruiting 250,000 volunteers to help spread the word about the importance of Firefox and the need for more alternative browsers. From this point on, the campaign will be running until late November/early December, with the goal of raising $50,000 in cash to support the full page advert.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Firefox 1.0 and its competition with Internet Explorer. Let me read through it carefully.

First, the text talks about how Firefox is a serious rival to Microsoft's Internet Explorer, which has just been released. People are excited because it's their first full version, but it's also gaining traction quickly. They're raising money for an ad in the New York Times.

Then it mentions Mozilla Foundation started development back in 1998 and made many features into Firefox, including Phoenix and Firebird before launching Firefox 1.0. Some security issues with Microsoft's IE are causing criticism from US computer security groups, which has helped them avoid using IE.

WebSideStory reports that about 95% of surfers use Firefox now, down to 92.9% by the end of October. They're responsible for slowly eroding IE's dominance. Mozilla says they've downloaded eight million times and plan to get a big chunk of net-browsing users. They have features like tab switching, pop-ups block, text finder, and threat monitoring.

Firefox is popular because it has fewer security holes than IE and has new features like tabs and threat monitoring. It also gained many browser extensions from Mozilla Foundation. A campaign raised $50k to get an ad in the NY Times, aiming to run later this year or next.

I need to make sure I capture all key points: Firefox's release as a main competitor, the campaign for the ad, their security issues, and their growth metrics.

Now, putting it together into a concise summary without explanations. Make sure to include the main ideas about competition, the campaign, security concerns, growth stats, features, and the overall status of Firefox.
</think>

Firefox 1.0 has emerged as a dominant competitor with Microsoft's Internet Explorer, driven by excitement from its first release and a growing ad campaign aimed at promoting it. Mozilla Foundation's open-source development contributed to Firefox' success, including features like tabs and threat monitoring. With about 95% of users switching to Firefox, they aim to strengthen their position despite security issues raised against Microsoft's browser. The campaign raises $50k for an ad in the NY Times, targeting a growing audience of net-based users.
tinyllama:1.1b: In conclusion, the FireStorm Browser is the first browser to take on Microsoft's Internet Explorer in its quest for a grip on the web-using population. It has managed to draw more users to itself by offering innovative features such as tabs and pop-up blocking, while being able to find text on pages easily through the search feature. The addition of many extensions, including Google toolbar and HomeLand Security, has also helped establish it as a worthy challenger to IE. As for Microsoft, their efforts are in vain, as Firefox's popularity has grown steadily and may soon surpass their browser.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Firefox has been designed by the Mozilla Foundation to take on Microsoft Internet Explorer, which had a considerable lead in terms of popularity among web surfers. The browser is being developed with an aim to erode this advantage for Microsoft by incorporating new features and technology that could potentially make IE less secure than before. 

The Firefox browser has also managed to attract significant attention from users who are looking for a different approach to web browsing, as it allows users to switch between various websites simultaneously, unlike Internet Explorer which relegates the task to only one tab at a time. Firefox also offers a range of extensions that developers can create and add to the browser's code, such as Google toolbar, a security check for text content, and a Homeland Security monitor that keeps users aware of current threat levels. 

A number of popular websites have started to incorporate extensions into their Firefox browsers, allowing them to provide enhanced features and services for users. For example, Google has developed a toolbar that can be installed in Firefox to keep users up-to-date with the latest news and information from Google, while SpamAssistant is another add-on that helps users to quickly identify spam messages sent through their email program. 

As of now, Firefox has been downloaded almost eight million times, a considerable number when compared to Internet Explorer's eight million users in late 2006. However, it could be argued that Firefox is already starting to take on Microsoft's primary browser, as the popularity and innovation of extensions can potentially reduce the security risks associated with using Internet Explorer. The Mozilla Foundation also plans to launch a campaign to raise $50,000 to fund a full-page advertisement in the New York Times, which will likely have a significant impact on the popularity of Firefox among users considering their web browser choices.
phi:2.7b: Firefox, developed by the Mozilla Foundation, has been gaining popularity due to its security features and user-friendly interface. It offers innovations like tabbed browsing and text search. Users can also customize their experience with numerous extensions created by the open source community. To raise funds for advertising in the New York Times, a campaign called Spread Firefox successfully attracted 10,000 volunteers and raised $250,000. This has put Firefox on the map as a serious contender to Microsoft's Internet Explorer. Other browsers like Opera, Safari, Amaya, and Netscape are also challenging IE's dominance.
orca-mini:3b: Firefox browser takes on Microsoft: Few people get excited when some new software is released, especially when the program is not a game or music or movie player. But the release of the first full version of Firefox has managed to drum up a respectable amount of pre-launch fervour. The release of Firefox 1.0 on 9 November might even cause a few heads to turn at Microsoft because the program is steadily winning people away from the software giant's Internet Explorer browser. The Mozilla Foundation, which was started by former browser maker Netscape back in 1998, has been behind the creation of Firefox. The software has been gaining praise and converts, not least because of the large number of security problems that have come to light in Microsoft's Internet Explorer. Rivals to IE got a boost in late June when two US computer security organizations warned people to avoid the Microsoft program to avoid falling victim to a serious vulnerability. Firefox has been downloaded almost eight million times and publicly says it would be happy to garner 10% of the Windows-using, net-browsing population.
hermes3:3b: Firefox browser competes with Microsoft's Internet Explorer, having released v1.0. Firefox gains popularity due to fewer security issues compared to IE, innovative features (tabs, pop-up blocking), and extensive open-source add-ons/extensions.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Firefox 1.0, created by the Mozilla Foundation, has been released and is gradually gaining popularity as a competitor to Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser. The Mozilla Foundation was started by former browser maker Netscape in 1998, and much of the development work since then has gone into Firefox. The software has attracted attention due to its fewer security holes compared to Internet Explorer and extra features like tabbed browsing and pop-up blocking. Since its release, Firefox has been downloaded almost eight million times. Microsoft is facing a growing challenge from alternative browsers such as Opera, Safari, Amaya, and Netscape.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Firefox 1.0, developed by the Mozilla Foundation, has been released as a strong competitor to Microsoft's Internet Explorer (IE). The browser has gained popularity due to its security advantages over IE and innovative features like tabbed browsing, pop-up blocking, and efficient text searching. Firefox has been downloaded nearly eight million times, contributing to a decline in IE's market share from 95% to 92.9% between July and October. The open-source nature of Firefox has led to numerous extensions, enhancing its functionality. A grassroots campaign raised $250,000—far exceeding its $50,000 goal—to fund a New York Times ad promoting Firefox. Microsoft faces increasing competition from alternative browsers, including Opera, Safari, and Netscape.
stablelm2:1.6b: Firefox has released its first full version and is winning users away from rival browser Internet Explorer. Created by the Mozilla Foundation, Firefox has been gaining popularity due to fewer security holes compared to Internet Explorer. It allows switching between websites with tabs, blocks pop-ups, and lets users search through pages. The foundation offers hundreds of extensions for Firefox. Microsoft's Internet Explorer usage dropped to 7% in October from 9% before that. Firefox aims to capture 10% of the Windows-using population. Its user base is growing due to its innovative features and extensive extension library.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Firefox 1.0, developed by the Mozilla Foundation (formerly Netscape), has been released with significant anticipation, surpassing Microsoft's Internet Explorer in market share among Windows users. Since its first appearance under this name in February, Firefox has gained popularity due to its robust security, innovative features like tabbed browsing and built-in text search, and a vast array of user-created extensions. Initially used by 95% of web surfers, Internet Explorer's market share dropped to 92.9% by October, signaling a growing challenge for Microsoft. Fans have rallied to finance an $80,000 New York Times ad, with over 10,000 volunteers contributing and raising approximately $250,000, which will support the Mozilla Foundation. The release of Firefox 1.0 marks a major victory for open-source browsers challenging Internet Explorer's dominance in the web browsing arena.
